required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Ex-vivo Perfusion and Ventilation of Lungs Recovered From Non-Heart-Beating Donors to Assess Transplant Suitability
clinical_study.official_title: Ex-vivo Perfusion and Ventilation of Lungs Recovered From Non-Heart-Beating Donors to Assess Transplant Suitability

lead_sponsor.agency: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

collaborator.agency: National Heart, Lung, and Blood Institute (NHLBI)

clinical_study.source: University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

brief_summary.textblock: The purpose of this research study is to learn about the safety of transplanting lungs obtained from non-heart-beating donors (NHBDs) that have been ventilated (attached to a breathing machine or ventilator to deliver oxygen) and perfused with a lung perfusion solution (Steen solution™, made by Vitrolife). This ventilation and perfusion will be done outside the body (ex-vivo) in a modified cardiopulmonary bypass circuit (the kind of device used routinely during most heart surgeries). The purpose of performing ex-vivo perfusion and ventilation is to learn how well the lungs work, and whether they are likely safe to transplant.

primary_outcome.description: The primary objective evaluated for this study is recipient mortality and graft survival at 30 days post transplant. 30 day mortality and graft survival is used as a standard research assessment to evaluate post transplant outcomes.

Primary Lung Graft Dysfunction (PGD) is an indicator for significant morbidity and mortality after lung transplantation. Grade 0: PaO2/FIO2 > 300 with normal chest radiograph; Grade 1: PaO2/FIO2 > 300 with diffuse infiltrates on the chest radiograph; Grade 2: PaO2/FIO2 between 200 and 300; Grade 3: PaO2/FIO2 < 200.

secondary_outcome.description: The length of ICU stay in days is another standard research and clinical outcome assessment post transplant and has been selected as a secondary objective.
Participants' status at Day 7 defined as the following: mechanical ventilation, extra-corporeal membrane oxygenator (ECMO), or extubated.
Recipient mortality at 12 months post transplant is being evaluated as a secondary objective.

secondary_outcome.measure: Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome (BOS) Free Graft Survival
secondary_outcome.description: Bronchiolitis Obliterans Syndrome (BOS) free graft survival at 12 months is being used as a secondary outcome.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) with STEEN Solution™
arm_group.description: The perfusion of the lungs will be performed using STEEN Solution™. The lungs will be physiologically assessed during ex vivo perfusion with STEEN Solution™ perfusate.

arm_group.arm_group_label: Lung transplant from conventional brain-dead organ donor
arm_group.description: No experimental procedures will be carried out.

intervention.intervention_name: Transplantation of lungs obtained from Non-Heart-Beating Donors (NHBDs) after ex-vivo perfusion w/ STEEN Solution™
intervention.description: After EVLP, lungs will be cooled in the circuit to room temperature, then flushed with cold Perfadex™, and taken to UNCH where they will have an ex-vivo CT scan. Lungs determined suitable will be offered to consented patients at UNC Hospitals and Duke University Medical Center based on Lung Allocation Score. Lungs not considered for transplantation may be subjected to different experiments but are not to be a part of this research study. In summary, lungs with good and stable function during EVLP will be transplanted into recipients as per current clinical practice.
intervention.arm_group_label: Ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) with STEEN Solution™

intervention.description: This solution is a buffered dextran and albumin-containing extracellular perfusate with an optimal colloid osmotic pressure developed specifically for extra-corporeal perfusion of lungs.
intervention.arm_group_label: Ex-vivo lung perfusion (EVLP) with STEEN Solution™

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- A recipient must meet the following requirement to enroll into the study:
- Requires a single or bilateral lung transplant and is listed for transplant at UNC or Duke
- Male or Female, 15 years of age or older.
- Subject or Subject's Representative provides a legally effective informed consent.
- Recipient does not have HIV, active Hepatitis or is colonized with Burkholderia cepacia.
- Potential subjects who have undergone previous lung transplants and meet all other inclusion criteria, are eligible for study participation.
Exclusion Criteria:
•Recipient fails to meet standard of care requirements for lung transplant, or decides not to participate.

Cypel M, Yeung JC, Liu M, Anraku M, Chen F, Karolak W, Sato M, Laratta J, Azad S, Madonik M, Chow CW, Chaparro C, Hutcheon M, Singer LG, Slutsky AS, Yasufuku K, de Perrot M, Pierre AF, Waddell TK, Keshavjee S. certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Lungs were recovered from 35 NHBDs, 22 had EVLP. 2 lung blocks were judged suitable for transplant. No consented recipient was available for one, the other could not be done for logistical reasons; so there were no subjects in the interventional arm.

point_of_contact.organization: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
